Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: First, I need to identify which cases have significantly longer total resolution times. To do this, I calculate the time taken for each case from 'Receive Ticket' to 'Close Ticket' and identify cases 105, 102, and 104 as significantly longer than cases 101 and 103.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Looking at cases with long resolution times, several patterns emerge: delays after escalation (e.g., Case 105 has a 26-hour gap before the next investigation), longer times for investigation and resolution after escalation, and less efficient escalation workflows.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The delays might be caused by resource constraints in the Level-2 team (causing backlog), mismanagement of case prioritization (escalated cases not prioritized enough), or inefficient handoffs (adding time between escalation and resolution steps).

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: If the escalation process itself includes manual or time-consuming steps, this could explain the delays. Additionally, Level-1 agents may lack the capacity or expertise to manage some tickets efficiently, leading to unnecessary escalations.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Across all cases with delays, escalation to Level-2 increases resolution times. Cases without escalation (e.g., 101 and 103) closed much faster, suggesting that Level-2 bottlenecks are a major contributor to delays.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Comparing timestamps, escalated cases consistently show longer gaps before investigation and resolution than non-escalated cases. This confirms that inefficiencies are most pronounced in the escalation workflow and post-escalation steps.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Based on these patterns, recommendations such as automating escalation steps, prioritizing escalated tickets, and improving resource allocation for Level-2 agents are likely to mitigate delays and reduce resolution times.
